thread.title: Australian stockmarket opens higher following with banks in spotlight
thread.title_full: Australian stockmarket opens higher following with banks in spotlight | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The Advertiser

author: MITCHELL NEEMS
title: Australian stockmarket opens higher following with banks in spotlight
text:
THE Australian sharemarket has pushed higher to start the week, following gains on Wall Street and as all eyes shift to bank stocks as the Commonwealth Bank comes out of a trading halt.
At 10.15am today, the benchmark ASX 200 index was up 14.1 points, or 0.26 per cent, at 5370.6 points.
The broader All Ordinaries rose 14.7 points, or 0.27 per cent, to 5374.7 points.
CMC chief market analyst Ric Spooner said investors would focus on profit results and bank stocks following a relatively steady lead from broader international markets on Friday.
"The question of whether or not bank stocks begin to attract buyer support once trading resumes in CBA will a key factor for overall market sentiment over the next couple of days," he said.
"With three of the big four banks now having completed capital raisings and Westpac this morning confirming a Tier 1 capital ratio of 10.5 per cent, investor focus is likely to return to the dividend yields offered by these stocks in a low growth environment."
No major local economic news is expected on Monday. In equities news, Newcrest, Aurizon, FlexiGroup and Mesoblast have all posted full-year results.
It was a volatile week on the Australian market last week with a fall due to weak commodity prices and subdued reaction to mixed company profit reports.
The ASX 200 ended the week down 31.4 points, or 0.58 per cent, at 5356.5 points.
The broader All Ordinaries index was down 29.0 points, or 0.54 per cent, at 5360.0 points.
 Aussie stocks open higher after gains in US
